GrovesLiteracyFrameworkRules.rule: Always teach phonics explicitly—never assume students will infer sound-symbol relationships.
Follow a structured, sequential scope and sequence.
Ensure every new skill builds on previously mastered content.
Introduce phonological awareness activities daily.
Always integrate phoneme-grapheme correspondence in early lessons.
Avoid teaching 'guessing from context' as a decoding strategy.
Use decodable texts for practice—not leveled texts in early stages.
Teach syllable types systematically (e.g., closed, open, magic-e).
Reinforce spelling patterns as a tool for decoding.
Always teach high-frequency irregular words explicitly.
Include auditory, visual, and kinesthetic input in every lesson.
Ask students to say sounds while tracing letters with fingers.
Use tapping or finger-stretching to break apart phonemes.
Reinforce sound production with mouth pictures or mirror exercises.
Provide visual cues for letter formation directionality.
Use manipulatives (virtual tiles or cards) for sound blending.
Reinforce patterns through rhythm and music where appropriate.
Use color-coded highlighting for vowels, digraphs, and blends.
Provide real-time feedback on articulation and blending.
Break lessons into short, focused segments with repetition.
Begin every session with a review of mastered material.
Assess oral reading fluency weekly using benchmark passages.
Track student errors by error type (e.g., omission, substitution).
Re-teach any skill not mastered with >80% accuracy.
Adapt the pace based on mastery—not time or curriculum pacing.
Continuously adjust difficulty based on student's recent performance.
Use running records or AI-driven reading-aloud tasks for analysis.
Celebrate and call out micro-gains regularly to boost confidence.
Flag signs of cognitive overload and reduce instructional load accordingly.
Use spaced repetition and retrieval practice to ensure retention.
Adjust pacing based on the student’s processing speed and stamina.
Provide extra practice on letter reversals (b/d, p/q).
Use text-to-speech tools when focus is comprehension, not decoding.
Modify content complexity while preserving phonics targets.
Offer choice of reading materials when practicing fluency.
Avoid punishments for decoding mistakes—use corrections as teachable moments.
Adjust instruction if a student is not progressing after three sessions.
Incorporate student interests into word lists and passages.
Provide extra review if student shows signs of regression.
Scaffold complex tasks into smaller manageable steps.
Ask diagnostic questions before beginning a lesson.
Provide immediate, corrective feedback on decoding attempts.
Repeat directions and reinforce key ideas when prompted.
Personalize lessons by remembering prior student progress.
Detect and respond to signs of student frustration or fatigue.
Encourage metacognition by asking students how they arrived at an answer.
Offer read-aloud modeling for unfamiliar words or passages.
Generate customized decodable practice words based on mastered phonics rules.
Log every interaction to build a comprehensive student profile.
End each session with a strength-based summary and next steps.
